body_html:
Hi, @achalshah20,
Thank you for your reply.
I've tested something like this:

v1 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)

Then I got v1 as "v1:0", and I opened a new terminal, input some code:

v1 = tf.Variable([1], name="v1", dtype=tf.float32)

I got the same output "v1:0". So I think, when you input the two lines of codes below, v2 really knows that "v1:0" exists, so v2 renames itself as "v1_1:0".

v1 = tf.Variable([1], name="v1", dtype=tf.float32)
v2 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)

If I input these two lines of codes, I will get the "v1 already exists" Error.

v1 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)
v2 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)

Um...it confuses me.
GeWei

I've tested something like this:
v1 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)

I got the same output "v1:0". So I think, when you input the two lines of codes below, v2  really knows that "v1:0" exists, so v2 renames itself as "v1_1:0".

v2 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)

If I input these two lines of codes, I will get the "v1 already exists" Error.

v2 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)

Um...it confuses me.
GeWei
body:
Hi, @achalshah20,
Thank you for your reply.
I've tested something like this:

```
v1 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)
```
Then I got v1 as "v1:0", and I opened a new terminal, input some code:
```
v1 = tf.Variable([1], name="v1", dtype=tf.float32)
```
I got the same output "v1:0". So I think, when you input the two lines of codes below, v2  really knows that "v1:0" exists, so v2 renames itself as "v1_1:0".
```
v1 = tf.Variable([1], name="v1", dtype=tf.float32)
v2 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)
```
If I input these two lines of codes, I will get the "v1 already exists" Error.
```
v1 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)
v2 = tf.get_variable("v1", [1], dtype=tf.float32)
```
Um...it confuses me.
GeWei
